article:
is tied for Major League records in both total times leading the league in
 saves (5) and consecutive league-leading seasons (4)|alt=A bearded man with his
 hands in his jacket pocets, wearing a red baseball cap and red jacket with a
 bird logo on the left chest, standing with a field and stands in the
 background.]] In baseball, a save is credited to a pitcher who finishes a game
 for the winning team under certain prescribed circumstances. Most commonly a
 relief pitcher ("reliever") earns a save by entering in the ninth inning of a
 game in which his team is winning by three or fewer runs and finishing the game
 by pitching one inning without losing the lead. The statistic was
 created by Jerome Holtzman in 1959 to "measure the effectiveness of relief
 pitchers" and was adopted as an official statistic by Major League Baseball
 (MLB) in 1969. The save has been retroactively measured
 for pitchers before that date.

MLB recognizes the player or players in each league with the most saves each
season. Although the statistic was not yet official, Jack Manning led the
National League in saves in its inaugural year with 5 while Bill Hoffer was the
American League's first saves champion with 3. Mordecai
Brown was the first pitcher to record at least 10 saves in a season. Dan
Quisenberry, Bruce Sutter, Firpo Marberry, and Ed Walsh are the only pitchers to
lead the league in saves five times (though Marberry and Walsh did so before
1969). Sutter is also tied with Harry Wright and Dan Quisenberry for the most
consecutive seasons leading the league in saves with four.
